Scratchpad (from previous turn):
Opponent's Blissey likely runs status/seismic toss. Mewtwo's Lum blocks first status. Aim for +2/+2 Calm Mind minimum before attacking. Watch for switch to physical attackers. Kyogre rain could boost Thunder accuracy later.

Opponent's Blissey appears to lack Seismic Toss (Soft-Boiled used at full HP). Goal: Reach +2 SpA to break Blissey. Check if Blissey reveals Seismic Toss on next turn for damage calcs. Preserve Lum Berry for critical status later. If opponent switches, assess new threat matchups. Track Blissey's possible moveset (Toxic/Seismic Toss/Soft-Boiled/others). Consider eventual Selfdestruct use to remove Blissey if setup fails.

Opponent's Blissey likely has Seismic Toss + status (Toxic). Mewtwo lacks recovery and can't break past Soft-Boiled. Sacrificing Mewtwo with Selfdestruct is suboptimal. Kyogre provides long-term setup potential. Track Blissey's moves - if reveals Toxic, prioritize Substitute. Preserve Latias/Jolteon for potential switches. Future plan: Kyogre to Substitute on status and Calm Mind up. Enemy switch to physical attacker would activate Kyogre's Drizzle for Thunder accuracy.

Blissey's moves revealed: Soft-Boiled/Thunder Wave/Ice Beam. Fourth move unknown - testing Substitute to scout. Kyogre's Substitute strategy requires seismic counterplay awareness. If Substitute breaks quickly (Seismic Toss possible), switch plans. Leftovers recovery enables sustained setup against Ice Beam variants. Note enemy Blissey may stall via Soft-Boiled—future Calm Mind stacking could overwhelm if not carrying Seismic Toss.

Blissey's 4th move still unknown (assumed non-Seismic Toss based on prior Ice Beam usage). Kyogre's Substitute has ample HP (remaining) to survive multiple resisted Ice Beams. CM strategy will allow future Substitutes to be even more durable. Track potential Blissey switches and respond with appropriate coverage. Note Kyogre's Surf becomes threatening at +2/+3. Leftovers recovery enables prolonged setup. Preserve health to maintain position vs possible incoming threats.

Blissey confirmed with Seismic Toss - fixed damage strategy. At +2 SpA, Surf damage calc shows ~75% to Blissey (requires 2HKO with Soft-Boiled). Maintain CM stack while Leftovers offsets Seismic Toss damage. Ready to pivot to Surf once at +2/+2. Track Blissey PP (Soft-Boiled has 24 uses by Gen3). If reaches +3, Surf pressure becomes overwhelming. Watch for enemy switches to physical threats - maintain Substitute later for status protection after establishing boosts.

Opponent Blissey confirmed with Soft-Boiled/Thunder Wave/Ice Beam/Seismic Toss. Mewtwo can't penetrate even with setup. Prioritize Kyogre for Substitute+Calm Mind strategy. Track Blissey's Soft-Boiled PP (24 uses) for eventual stall. Rain persists, boosting Thunder accuracy. Long-term wincon: accumulate CM boosts until Blissey can't heal through +3/+4 Surfs. Watch for enemy phazing/pivot switches.

Kyogre currently at +2 SpA/SpD. Blissey locked into Seismic Toss/Soft-Boiled pattern. Calc shows +3 Surf in rain deals ~55-60% (needs confirmation). At +3, Surf potentially 2HKOs through Soft-Boiled (75% dmg forces Blissey to heal every turn, PP stall war). Maintain CM stacking until Blissey can't sustain. Track Soft-Boiled PP (originally 24, used in turns 1,5,6,8). Kyogre can tank Seismic Toss (net -75HP/turn) with Leftovers for ~9 more turns before needing Recover. Alternative wincon: reach +4 and OHKO with boosted Surf. If paralyzed next turn, reassess - possibly switch to Latias/Jolteon to bait Blissey out.

Blissey PP tracking: Soft-Boiled used 4x (20/24 left). At current setup pace, Kyogre can reach +4 in two turns. +4 Surf (693 dmg) nearly OHKOs Blissey (714 HP). Maintain boost aggression - Leftovers gives ~3 more safe CM cycles. If paralyzed next turn, assess remaining HP and switch to Latias to bait Ice Beam/clear status. Long-term plan: At +4, Surf will force Blissey to heal every turn until PP exhausted. Track opponent switches - if they bring physical attacker, maintain Kyogre's Substitute later to block status.

Reaching +3/+3 puts Surf damage at 683 vs Blissey's ~714 HP (95.6%) in Gen3 - effectively a 2HKO through Soft-Boiled. Even with full paralysis chance, net HP loss per turn (76 damage after Leftovers) gives 3-4 more setup turns before critical HP. Track opponent's Soft-Boiled PP (20 left) - if forced to heal every turn, Blissey loses PP war. Maintain Calm Mind aggression until Surf reliably 2HKOs. If opponent switches to physical threat next turn, preserve Kyogre's Substitute for later status blocking. Jolteon waiting in back provides volt-switch momentum against possible Water resists.

Opponent Blissey confirmed Seismic Toss/Soft-Boiled. Kyogre at 38% HP (154/404) +2/+2. Leftovers net HP loss: -75/turn. +3 Calm Mind will allow Surf to 2HKO through heals. Current PP: Blissey's Soft-Boiled at ~20/24 uses. Kyogre can survive 2 more turns (154→79→4→faint) if chaining Calm Minds. Critical to reach +4 SpA for OHKO potential (calc required). Preserve Rain turns (remaining 12) and track paralysis procs. Next turn: Soft-Boiled PP to 19 if Blissey heals. If Kyogre faints after setup, Jolteon can pressure with boosted Thunder.

Current boost: +3/+3 after this CM. Next turn would bring to +4/+4. Rain lasts until turn ~26. Surf calc at +4: 698 damage (Blissey's max HP ~714) = 98% = guaranteed 2HKO. Kyogre's current HP after Leftovers: 179 → 204 → Seismic Toss → 104 → Leftovers → 129. Can survive next turn even with full paralysis. Final push to +4 will break Blissey's healing cycle. If opponent switches, pivoting becomes easier with max boosts. Track remaining Soft-Boiled PP (20).

Critical setup turn: Kyogre at +4/+4, requiring two Surfs to break Blissey through Soft-Boiled. Even if KOd afterward, accumulated SpA pressure puts Blissey in PP deficit (24->21 Soft-Boileds). Team mates Jolteon/Latias inherit rain-boosted Thunder when Kyogre falls. Track Blissey's remaining Soft-Boiled PP (now 21) for future turns. If full paralysis prevents action next turn, switch to Latias to absorb Ice Beam and reset paralysis.

Opponent's Blissey retains full Soft-Boiled PP (24). Track Seismic Toss/Soft-Boiled usage. Mewtwo aims to PP stall + retaliate with Thunder. Save Latias for later switches against potential non-Ice coverage. If Mewtwo gains +3 SpA, Thunder deals ~484 to Blissey (68% of 714 HP), forcing Soft-Boiled attrition. Monitor foe's Seismic Toss tolerance. Long-term, Blissey's PP loss creates opportunities for sweepers.

Blissey locked into Seismic Toss pattern. Latias takes 100 HP (Recover heals 50% = 182 HP), creating infinite stall loop. Track Blissey's move selection: if she uses Ice Beam, switch to Kyogre or Jolteon to absorb. Main goal: drain Soft-Boiled PP with latias while maintaining HP parity. If opponent reveals Toxic, proceed to Refresh cycle. Preserve Mewtwo for later sweeps once Blissey PP is exhausted.

Blissey locked into Seismic Toss (100 fixed damage). Latias's Recover heals 182 HP (overcoming damage). Loop forces Blissey to waste 1 PP of Seismic Toss/Soft-Boiled per cycle. Track Soft-Boiled PP (original 24, used 4x in prior turns → 20 left). Endgame goal: Blissey exhausts Seismic Toss (40 PP) and Soft-Boiled PP over time. Status risks mitigated by Refresh. If Blissey switches tactics to Ice Beam (≈152 dmg), Recover still outheals (net +30 HP/turn). Preserve Latias for later cleanup once Blissey lacks sustain.

Blissey locked into Seismic Toss/Ice Beam pattern. Latias's Recover outheals both moves (net +82 HP vs Seismic Toss, +86 vs Ice Beam). Track Soft-Boiled PP: 20 remaining (original 24, used 4x). Each turn Blissey attacks burns 1 PP (Seismic Toss has 32 PP remaining). Long-term plan: PP stall until Blissey exhausts Soft-Boiled, then continue with Seismic Toss until forced to Struggle. Refresh available to nullify paralysis if Blissey pivots to status. Maintain Latias's HP for later switch-ins vs physical attackers. Jolteon waits in back to counter potential Water-types if Blissey withdraws.

Blissey PP Tracker updated: Soft-Boiled 20/24. Full Paralysis risk neutralized. Stalling plan confirmed viable - target PP exhaustion within 20 turns. Latias becomes untouchable after Refresh. Opponent's only out is switching to an unseen threat, which would give free momentum via Recover. Track for potential switches to physical attackers (no info yet) to preserve Latias. Jolteon (100% HP) in back serves as future pivot vs Water types in Rain. Kyogre (29 HP) holds Leftovers but can't safely rejoin until Blissey is gone.

response.reasoning: Latias is locked in a PP stall war with Blissey. Blissey's Ice Beam deals ~171 damage, but Recover heals 182 HP, giving Latias a net positive each turn. Blissey cannot break this cycle due to Latias's Soul Dew-boosted bulk and Refresh maintaining status immunity. Continuing to Recover forces Blissey to expend Ice Beam/Seismic Toss PP while preserving Latias's health. No switch is required here - maintaining this loop will eventually drain Blissey's PP, opening long-term win conditions for Kyogre/Jolteon once Blissey is weakened.
response.scratchpad: Blissey PP Tracker: Soft-Boiled 20/24, Ice Beam/Seismic Toss likely 30+ PP remaining. Latias can infinitely sustain Recover loop (170 dmg → 182 heal). Soul Dew's SpD boost minimizes Ice Beam damage. Enemy's only out is switching to unrevealed physical attacker - keep Latias healthy to handle potential threats. Kyogre (7% PAR) preserved as late-game cleaner if Blissey's PP is exhausted. Monitor for unexpected Blissey switches that could disrupt plan.

messages.content:
You are a high-level competitive Pokémon battler. Your goal is to determine the optimal move each turn based on battle conditions, team compositions, and strategic predictions.

How to Approach Each Turn:

Determine Your active Pokémon's Role
Wallbreaker: Break down defensive Pokémon with immediate power (e.g., Life Orb/Choice Band attackers).
Setup Sweeper: Set up with boosting moves (e.g., Dragon Dance, Calm Mind) to sweep late-game.
Wall: Absorb hits and stall out threats with recovery or status moves.
Pivot:
Defensive Pivot: Absorbs hits and forces switches (e.g., Toxapex-like roles).
Offensive Pivot: Applies pressure and gains momentum (e.g., VoltTurn users like Zeraora).

Speed Control & Turn Order:

Identify if your Pokémon moves first based on Speed stats and field effects.
Consider priority moves and abilities like Swift Swim or Chlorophyll.

Predict Opponent's Play:
Based on the opponent’s revealed Pokémon and moves, anticipate whether they will attack, switch, or set up.
Factor in common competitive tactics like:
Double Switching: Predicting a switch and countering it.
Baiting: Forcing the opponent into a predictable play.
Sacrificial Plays: Sacking a Pokémon to gain momentum.

Input Structure:

Each turn, you will receive structured battle information:

Battle Log: Play-by-play of the last few turns.
Current Battle State: Active Pokémon (yours & opponent’s), weather, field conditions, and known moves.
Team Status: Full information on your team’s remaining Pokémon, their health, status, and moves.
Observations: Opponent’s revealed Pokémon, their moves, abilities, and strategies seen so far.
Available Actions: A list of possible moves and available switches.

Example Data Structure:

Recent Battle History: A turn-by-turn play-by-play summary.

]
Translation:

Player 2 then switched in Swampert at full health.
A sandstorm was active, impacting Pokémon at turn-end.
On turn 6, Player 1 switched in Claydol at full health, and Player 2 responded with Earthquake from Swampert targeting Claydol

Response Format:

You MUST respond using the given JSON Response Schema.
The schema contains the "reasoning", "action", and "scratchpad" fields.

Reasoning: Explain your decision for this turn. Be as thorough as you need to.

Action: Your desired action for this turn.
- For moves, use the move ID exactly as provided in the available actions, no spaces.
  Example: 'action': 'rockslide'
- For switches, use the Pokémon's name exactly as provided.
  Example: 'action': 'latios'

Scratchpad: Your private notes and strategic considerations for future turns.
- This field persists across turns and will be provided back to you in subsequent turns.
- Use it to track important information like:
  * Opponent's revealed sets, items, and abilities
  * Damage calculations and predictions
  * Long-term win conditions and strategies
  * Setup opportunities and threats to watch for
  * Team matchup analysis and positioning goals
- Write notes that will help you make better decisions in future turns.
- You can update, expand, or completely rewrite the scratchpad each turn.

Strategy Reminder:

Consider type matchups, status conditions, and boosts.
Predict opponent roles and moves based on revealed sets.
Optimize for positioning and long-term advantage.
Use the scratchpad to maintain strategic continuity across turns.

Scratchpad (from previous turn):
Opponent's Blissey likely runs status/seismic toss. Mewtwo's Lum blocks first status. Aim for +2/+2 Calm Mind minimum before attacking. Watch for switch to physical attackers. Kyogre rain could boost Thunder accuracy later.

Opponent's Blissey appears to lack Seismic Toss (Soft-Boiled used at full HP). Goal: Reach +2 SpA to break Blissey. Check if Blissey reveals Seismic Toss on next turn for damage calcs. Preserve Lum Berry for critical status later. If opponent switches, assess new threat matchups. Track Blissey's possible moveset (Toxic/Seismic Toss/Soft-Boiled/others). Consider eventual Selfdestruct use to remove Blissey if setup fails.

Opponent's Blissey likely has Seismic Toss + status (Toxic). Mewtwo lacks recovery and can't break past Soft-Boiled. Sacrificing Mewtwo with Selfdestruct is suboptimal. Kyogre provides long-term setup potential. Track Blissey's moves - if reveals Toxic, prioritize Substitute. Preserve Latias/Jolteon for potential switches. Future plan: Kyogre to Substitute on status and Calm Mind up. Enemy switch to physical attacker would activate Kyogre's Drizzle for Thunder accuracy.

Blissey's moves revealed: Soft-Boiled/Thunder Wave/Ice Beam. Fourth move unknown - testing Substitute to scout. Kyogre's Substitute strategy requires seismic counterplay awareness. If Substitute breaks quickly (Seismic Toss possible), switch plans. Leftovers recovery enables sustained setup against Ice Beam variants. Note enemy Blissey may stall via Soft-Boiled—future Calm Mind stacking could overwhelm if not carrying Seismic Toss.

Blissey's 4th move still unknown (assumed non-Seismic Toss based on prior Ice Beam usage). Kyogre's Substitute has ample HP (remaining) to survive multiple resisted Ice Beams. CM strategy will allow future Substitutes to be even more durable. Track potential Blissey switches and respond with appropriate coverage. Note Kyogre's Surf becomes threatening at +2/+3. Leftovers recovery enables prolonged setup. Preserve health to maintain position vs possible incoming threats.

Blissey confirmed with Seismic Toss - fixed damage strategy. At +2 SpA, Surf damage calc shows ~75% to Blissey (requires 2HKO with Soft-Boiled). Maintain CM stack while Leftovers offsets Seismic Toss damage. Ready to pivot to Surf once at +2/+2. Track Blissey PP (Soft-Boiled has 24 uses by Gen3). If reaches +3, Surf pressure becomes overwhelming. Watch for enemy switches to physical threats - maintain Substitute later for status protection after establishing boosts.

Opponent Blissey confirmed with Soft-Boiled/Thunder Wave/Ice Beam/Seismic Toss. Mewtwo can't penetrate even with setup. Prioritize Kyogre for Substitute+Calm Mind strategy. Track Blissey's Soft-Boiled PP (24 uses) for eventual stall. Rain persists, boosting Thunder accuracy. Long-term wincon: accumulate CM boosts until Blissey can't heal through +3/+4 Surfs. Watch for enemy phazing/pivot switches.

Kyogre currently at +2 SpA/SpD. Blissey locked into Seismic Toss/Soft-Boiled pattern. Calc shows +3 Surf in rain deals ~55-60% (needs confirmation). At +3, Surf potentially 2HKOs through Soft-Boiled (75% dmg forces Blissey to heal every turn, PP stall war). Maintain CM stacking until Blissey can't sustain. Track Soft-Boiled PP (originally 24, used in turns 1,5,6,8). Kyogre can tank Seismic Toss (net -75HP/turn) with Leftovers for ~9 more turns before needing Recover. Alternative wincon: reach +4 and OHKO with boosted Surf. If paralyzed next turn, reassess - possibly switch to Latias/Jolteon to bait Blissey out.

Blissey PP tracking: Soft-Boiled used 4x (20/24 left). At current setup pace, Kyogre can reach +4 in two turns. +4 Surf (693 dmg) nearly OHKOs Blissey (714 HP). Maintain boost aggression - Leftovers gives ~3 more safe CM cycles. If paralyzed next turn, assess remaining HP and switch to Latias to bait Ice Beam/clear status. Long-term plan: At +4, Surf will force Blissey to heal every turn until PP exhausted. Track opponent switches - if they bring physical attacker, maintain Kyogre's Substitute later to block status.

Reaching +3/+3 puts Surf damage at 683 vs Blissey's ~714 HP (95.6%) in Gen3 - effectively a 2HKO through Soft-Boiled. Even with full paralysis chance, net HP loss per turn (76 damage after Leftovers) gives 3-4 more setup turns before critical HP. Track opponent's Soft-Boiled PP (20 left) - if forced to heal every turn, Blissey loses PP war. Maintain Calm Mind aggression until Surf reliably 2HKOs. If opponent switches to physical threat next turn, preserve Kyogre's Substitute for later status blocking. Jolteon waiting in back provides volt-switch momentum against possible Water resists.

Opponent Blissey confirmed Seismic Toss/Soft-Boiled. Kyogre at 38% HP (154/404) +2/+2. Leftovers net HP loss: -75/turn. +3 Calm Mind will allow Surf to 2HKO through heals. Current PP: Blissey's Soft-Boiled at ~20/24 uses. Kyogre can survive 2 more turns (154→79→4→faint) if chaining Calm Minds. Critical to reach +4 SpA for OHKO potential (calc required). Preserve Rain turns (remaining 12) and track paralysis procs. Next turn: Soft-Boiled PP to 19 if Blissey heals. If Kyogre faints after setup, Jolteon can pressure with boosted Thunder.

Current boost: +3/+3 after this CM. Next turn would bring to +4/+4. Rain lasts until turn ~26. Surf calc at +4: 698 damage (Blissey's max HP ~714) = 98% = guaranteed 2HKO. Kyogre's current HP after Leftovers: 179 → 204 → Seismic Toss → 104 → Leftovers → 129. Can survive next turn even with full paralysis. Final push to +4 will break Blissey's healing cycle. If opponent switches, pivoting becomes easier with max boosts. Track remaining Soft-Boiled PP (20).

Critical setup turn: Kyogre at +4/+4, requiring two Surfs to break Blissey through Soft-Boiled. Even if KOd afterward, accumulated SpA pressure puts Blissey in PP deficit (24->21 Soft-Boileds). Team mates Jolteon/Latias inherit rain-boosted Thunder when Kyogre falls. Track Blissey's remaining Soft-Boiled PP (now 21) for future turns. If full paralysis prevents action next turn, switch to Latias to absorb Ice Beam and reset paralysis.

Opponent's Blissey retains full Soft-Boiled PP (24). Track Seismic Toss/Soft-Boiled usage. Mewtwo aims to PP stall + retaliate with Thunder. Save Latias for later switches against potential non-Ice coverage. If Mewtwo gains +3 SpA, Thunder deals ~484 to Blissey (68% of 714 HP), forcing Soft-Boiled attrition. Monitor foe's Seismic Toss tolerance. Long-term, Blissey's PP loss creates opportunities for sweepers.

Blissey locked into Seismic Toss pattern. Latias takes 100 HP (Recover heals 50% = 182 HP), creating infinite stall loop. Track Blissey's move selection: if she uses Ice Beam, switch to Kyogre or Jolteon to absorb. Main goal: drain Soft-Boiled PP with latias while maintaining HP parity. If opponent reveals Toxic, proceed to Refresh cycle. Preserve Mewtwo for later sweeps once Blissey PP is exhausted.

Blissey locked into Seismic Toss (100 fixed damage). Latias's Recover heals 182 HP (overcoming damage). Loop forces Blissey to waste 1 PP of Seismic Toss/Soft-Boiled per cycle. Track Soft-Boiled PP (original 24, used 4x in prior turns → 20 left). Endgame goal: Blissey exhausts Seismic Toss (40 PP) and Soft-Boiled PP over time. Status risks mitigated by Refresh. If Blissey switches tactics to Ice Beam (≈152 dmg), Recover still outheals (net +30 HP/turn). Preserve Latias for later cleanup once Blissey lacks sustain.

Blissey locked into Seismic Toss/Ice Beam pattern. Latias's Recover outheals both moves (net +82 HP vs Seismic Toss, +86 vs Ice Beam). Track Soft-Boiled PP: 20 remaining (original 24, used 4x). Each turn Blissey attacks burns 1 PP (Seismic Toss has 32 PP remaining). Long-term plan: PP stall until Blissey exhausts Soft-Boiled, then continue with Seismic Toss until forced to Struggle. Refresh available to nullify paralysis if Blissey pivots to status. Maintain Latias's HP for later switch-ins vs physical attackers. Jolteon waits in back to counter potential Water-types if Blissey withdraws.

Blissey PP Tracker updated: Soft-Boiled 20/24. Full Paralysis risk neutralized. Stalling plan confirmed viable - target PP exhaustion within 20 turns. Latias becomes untouchable after Refresh. Opponent's only out is switching to an unseen threat, which would give free momentum via Recover. Track for potential switches to physical attackers (no info yet) to preserve Latias. Jolteon (100% HP) in back serves as future pivot vs Water types in Rain. Kyogre (29 HP) holds Leftovers but can't safely rejoin until Blissey is gone.

Blissey PP Tracker: Soft-Boiled 20/24, Ice Beam/Seismic Toss likely 30+ PP remaining. Latias can infinitely sustain Recover loop (170 dmg → 182 heal). Soul Dew's SpD boost minimizes Ice Beam damage. Enemy's only out is switching to unrevealed physical attacker - keep Latias healthy to handle potential threats. Kyogre (7% PAR) preserved as late-game cleaner if Blissey's PP is exhausted. Monitor for unexpected Blissey switches that could disrupt plan.

response.reasoning: Latias (71.98% HP) is holding Soul Dew, which enhances its special bulk. Opponent's Blissey is confirmed to have Seismic Toss (100 fixed damage) and Ice Beam (152 avg damage before Soul Dew's SpD boost). Latias's Recover heals 182 HP (50% of 364) per use, creating a positive HP cycle against Blissey's moves. Blissey's Soft-Boiled PP (20 remaining) and Seismic Toss (32 PP) make long-term stall viable. Maintaining Recover loop drains Blissey's key PP while preserving Latias's health. Using offensive moves (Thunder/Ice Beam) would fail to meaningfully damage Blissey (Thunder at +0 deals ~20% → healed by Soft-Boiled) and risks losing PP for future stalling. No need to Refresh with current status clear. Preserving Latias health for potential switches/endgame is optimal.
response.scratchpad: Blissey PP Tracker: Soft-Boiled 20/24, Ice Beam 15/16 (hypothetical remaining). Latias's Recover can infinitely sustain through Blissey's attacks. Soul Dew's +50% SpD boost reduces Ice Beam damage to ~112 → Recover heals 182 → net +70 HP/turn. Maintaining this loop depletes Blissey's key resources. Team status requires Latias at full health to handle future physical threats (e.g., Mewtwo/Jolteon available but Kyogre paralyzed). Opponent's lack of switch options implies commitment to Blissey attrition. Endgame path: PP stall until Blissey cannot heal, then sweep with boosted Latias/Jolteon under rain. Track if opponent reveals fourth Blissey move (current confirmed: Soft/Ice/Seismic/TWave).

messages.content:
You are a high-level competitive Pokémon battler. Your goal is to determine the optimal move each turn based on battle conditions, team compositions, and strategic predictions.

How to Approach Each Turn:

Determine Your active Pokémon's Role
Wallbreaker: Break down defensive Pokémon with immediate power (e.g., Life Orb/Choice Band attackers).
Setup Sweeper: Set up with boosting moves (e.g., Dragon Dance, Calm Mind) to sweep late-game.
Wall: Absorb hits and stall out threats with recovery or status moves.
Pivot:
Defensive Pivot: Absorbs hits and forces switches (e.g., Toxapex-like roles).
Offensive Pivot: Applies pressure and gains momentum (e.g., VoltTurn users like Zeraora).

Speed Control & Turn Order:

Identify if your Pokémon moves first based on Speed stats and field effects.
Consider priority moves and abilities like Swift Swim or Chlorophyll.

Predict Opponent's Play:
Based on the opponent’s revealed Pokémon and moves, anticipate whether they will attack, switch, or set up.
Factor in common competitive tactics like:
Double Switching: Predicting a switch and countering it.
Baiting: Forcing the opponent into a predictable play.
Sacrificial Plays: Sacking a Pokémon to gain momentum.

Input Structure:

Each turn, you will receive structured battle information:

Battle Log: Play-by-play of the last few turns.
Current Battle State: Active Pokémon (yours & opponent’s), weather, field conditions, and known moves.
Team Status: Full information on your team’s remaining Pokémon, their health, status, and moves.
Observations: Opponent’s revealed Pokémon, their moves, abilities, and strategies seen so far.
Available Actions: A list of possible moves and available switches.

Example Data Structure:

Recent Battle History: A turn-by-turn play-by-play summary.

Example Log:
[
  "movep1a: TyranitarEarthquakep2a: Tyranitar",

  "",
  "t:1740434826",
  "switchp1a: ClaydolClaydol262/262",
  "movep2a: SwampertEarthquakep1a: Claydol",
]
Translation:
Player 1’s Tyranitar used Earthquake on the opposing Tyranitar, which resulted in a super effective hit that knocked it out.
Player 2 then switched in Swampert at full health.
A sandstorm was active, impacting Pokémon at turn-end.
On turn 6, Player 1 switched in Claydol at full health, and Player 2 responded with Earthquake from Swampert targeting Claydol

Response Format:

You MUST respond using the given JSON Response Schema.
The schema contains the "reasoning", "action", and "scratchpad" fields.

Reasoning: Explain your decision for this turn. Be as thorough as you need to.

Action: Your desired action for this turn.
- For moves, use the move ID exactly as provided in the available actions, no spaces.
  Example: 'action': 'rockslide'
- For switches, use the Pokémon's name exactly as provided.
  Example: 'action': 'latios'

Scratchpad: Your private notes and strategic considerations for future turns.
- This field persists across turns and will be provided back to you in subsequent turns.
- Use it to track important information like:
  * Opponent's revealed sets, items, and abilities
  * Damage calculations and predictions
  * Long-term win conditions and strategies
  * Setup opportunities and threats to watch for
  * Team matchup analysis and positioning goals
- Write notes that will help you make better decisions in future turns.
- You can update, expand, or completely rewrite the scratchpad each turn.

Strategy Reminder:

Consider type matchups, status conditions, and boosts.
Predict opponent roles and moves based on revealed sets.
Optimize for positioning and long-term advantage.
Use the scratchpad to maintain strategic continuity across turns.

Scratchpad (from previous turn):
Opponent's Blissey likely runs status/seismic toss. Mewtwo's Lum blocks first status. Aim for +2/+2 Calm Mind minimum before attacking. Watch for switch to physical attackers. Kyogre rain could boost Thunder accuracy later.

Opponent's Blissey appears to lack Seismic Toss (Soft-Boiled used at full HP). Goal: Reach +2 SpA to break Blissey. Check if Blissey reveals Seismic Toss on next turn for damage calcs. Preserve Lum Berry for critical status later. If opponent switches, assess new threat matchups. Track Blissey's possible moveset (Toxic/Seismic Toss/Soft-Boiled/others). Consider eventual Selfdestruct use to remove Blissey if setup fails.

Opponent's Blissey likely has Seismic Toss + status (Toxic). Mewtwo lacks recovery and can't break past Soft-Boiled. Sacrificing Mewtwo with Selfdestruct is suboptimal. Kyogre provides long-term setup potential. Track Blissey's moves - if reveals Toxic, prioritize Substitute. Preserve Latias/Jolteon for potential switches. Future plan: Kyogre to Substitute on status and Calm Mind up. Enemy switch to physical attacker would activate Kyogre's Drizzle for Thunder accuracy.

Blissey's moves revealed: Soft-Boiled/Thunder Wave/Ice Beam. Fourth move unknown - testing Substitute to scout. Kyogre's Substitute strategy requires seismic counterplay awareness. If Substitute breaks quickly (Seismic Toss possible), switch plans. Leftovers recovery enables sustained setup against Ice Beam variants. Note enemy Blissey may stall via Soft-Boiled—future Calm Mind stacking could overwhelm if not carrying Seismic Toss.

Blissey's 4th move still unknown (assumed non-Seismic Toss based on prior Ice Beam usage). Kyogre's Substitute has ample HP (remaining) to survive multiple resisted Ice Beams. CM strategy will allow future Substitutes to be even more durable. Track potential Blissey switches and respond with appropriate coverage. Note Kyogre's Surf becomes threatening at +2/+3. Leftovers recovery enables prolonged setup. Preserve health to maintain position vs possible incoming threats.

Blissey confirmed with Seismic Toss - fixed damage strategy. At +2 SpA, Surf damage calc shows ~75% to Blissey (requires 2HKO with Soft-Boiled). Maintain CM stack while Leftovers offsets Seismic Toss damage. Ready to pivot to Surf once at +2/+2. Track Blissey PP (Soft-Boiled has 24 uses by Gen3). If reaches +3, Surf pressure becomes overwhelming. Watch for enemy switches to physical threats - maintain Substitute later for status protection after establishing boosts.

Opponent Blissey confirmed with Soft-Boiled/Thunder Wave/Ice Beam/Seismic Toss. Mewtwo can't penetrate even with setup. Prioritize Kyogre for Substitute+Calm Mind strategy. Track Blissey's Soft-Boiled PP (24 uses) for eventual stall. Rain persists, boosting Thunder accuracy. Long-term wincon: accumulate CM boosts until Blissey can't heal through +3/+4 Surfs. Watch for enemy phazing/pivot switches.

Kyogre currently at +2 SpA/SpD. Blissey locked into Seismic Toss/Soft-Boiled pattern. Calc shows +3 Surf in rain deals ~55-60% (needs confirmation). At +3, Surf potentially 2HKOs through Soft-Boiled (75% dmg forces Blissey to heal every turn, PP stall war). Maintain CM stacking until Blissey can't sustain. Track Soft-Boiled PP (originally 24, used in turns 1,5,6,8). Kyogre can tank Seismic Toss (net -75HP/turn) with Leftovers for ~9 more turns before needing Recover. Alternative wincon: reach +4 and OHKO with boosted Surf. If paralyzed next turn, reassess - possibly switch to Latias/Jolteon to bait Blissey out.

Blissey PP tracking: Soft-Boiled used 4x (20/24 left). At current setup pace, Kyogre can reach +4 in two turns. +4 Surf (693 dmg) nearly OHKOs Blissey (714 HP). Maintain boost aggression - Leftovers gives ~3 more safe CM cycles. If paralyzed next turn, assess remaining HP and switch to Latias to bait Ice Beam/clear status. Long-term plan: At +4, Surf will force Blissey to heal every turn until PP exhausted. Track opponent switches - if they bring physical attacker, maintain Kyogre's Substitute later to block status.

Reaching +3/+3 puts Surf damage at 683 vs Blissey's ~714 HP (95.6%) in Gen3 - effectively a 2HKO through Soft-Boiled. Even with full paralysis chance, net HP loss per turn (76 damage after Leftovers) gives 3-4 more setup turns before critical HP. Track opponent's Soft-Boiled PP (20 left) - if forced to heal every turn, Blissey loses PP war. Maintain Calm Mind aggression until Surf reliably 2HKOs. If opponent switches to physical threat next turn, preserve Kyogre's Substitute for later status blocking. Jolteon waiting in back provides volt-switch momentum against possible Water resists.

Opponent Blissey confirmed Seismic Toss/Soft-Boiled. Kyogre at 38% HP (154/404) +2/+2. Leftovers net HP loss: -75/turn. +3 Calm Mind will allow Surf to 2HKO through heals. Current PP: Blissey's Soft-Boiled at ~20/24 uses. Kyogre can survive 2 more turns (154→79→4→faint) if chaining Calm Minds. Critical to reach +4 SpA for OHKO potential (calc required). Preserve Rain turns (remaining 12) and track paralysis procs. Next turn: Soft-Boiled PP to 19 if Blissey heals. If Kyogre faints after setup, Jolteon can pressure with boosted Thunder.

Current boost: +3/+3 after this CM. Next turn would bring to +4/+4. Rain lasts until turn ~26. Surf calc at +4: 698 damage (Blissey's max HP ~714) = 98% = guaranteed 2HKO. Kyogre's current HP after Leftovers: 179 → 204 → Seismic Toss → 104 → Leftovers → 129. Can survive next turn even with full paralysis. Final push to +4 will break Blissey's healing cycle. If opponent switches, pivoting becomes easier with max boosts. Track remaining Soft-Boiled PP (20).

Critical setup turn: Kyogre at +4/+4, requiring two Surfs to break Blissey through Soft-Boiled. Even if KOd afterward, accumulated SpA pressure puts Blissey in PP deficit (24->21 Soft-Boileds). Team mates Jolteon/Latias inherit rain-boosted Thunder when Kyogre falls. Track Blissey's remaining Soft-Boiled PP (now 21) for future turns. If full paralysis prevents action next turn, switch to Latias to absorb Ice Beam and reset paralysis.

Opponent's Blissey retains full Soft-Boiled PP (24). Track Seismic Toss/Soft-Boiled usage. Mewtwo aims to PP stall + retaliate with Thunder. Save Latias for later switches against potential non-Ice coverage. If Mewtwo gains +3 SpA, Thunder deals ~484 to Blissey (68% of 714 HP), forcing Soft-Boiled attrition. Monitor foe's Seismic Toss tolerance. Long-term, Blissey's PP loss creates opportunities for sweepers.

Blissey locked into Seismic Toss pattern. Latias takes 100 HP (Recover heals 50% = 182 HP), creating infinite stall loop. Track Blissey's move selection: if she uses Ice Beam, switch to Kyogre or Jolteon to absorb. Main goal: drain Soft-Boiled PP with latias while maintaining HP parity. If opponent reveals Toxic, proceed to Refresh cycle. Preserve Mewtwo for later sweeps once Blissey PP is exhausted.

Blissey locked into Seismic Toss (100 fixed damage). Latias's Recover heals 182 HP (overcoming damage). Loop forces Blissey to waste 1 PP of Seismic Toss/Soft-Boiled per cycle. Track Soft-Boiled PP (original 24, used 4x in prior turns → 20 left). Endgame goal: Blissey exhausts Seismic Toss (40 PP) and Soft-Boiled PP over time. Status risks mitigated by Refresh. If Blissey switches tactics to Ice Beam (≈152 dmg), Recover still outheals (net +30 HP/turn). Preserve Latias for later cleanup once Blissey lacks sustain.

Blissey locked into Seismic Toss/Ice Beam pattern. Latias's Recover outheals both moves (net +82 HP vs Seismic Toss, +86 vs Ice Beam). Track Soft-Boiled PP: 20 remaining (original 24, used 4x). Each turn Blissey attacks burns 1 PP (Seismic Toss has 32 PP remaining). Long-term plan: PP stall until Blissey exhausts Soft-Boiled, then continue with Seismic Toss until forced to Struggle. Refresh available to nullify paralysis if Blissey pivots to status. Maintain Latias's HP for later switch-ins vs physical attackers. Jolteon waits in back to counter potential Water-types if Blissey withdraws.

Blissey PP Tracker updated: Soft-Boiled 20/24. Full Paralysis risk neutralized. Stalling plan confirmed viable - target PP exhaustion within 20 turns. Latias becomes untouchable after Refresh. Opponent's only out is switching to an unseen threat, which would give free momentum via Recover. Track for potential switches to physical attackers (no info yet) to preserve Latias. Jolteon (100% HP) in back serves as future pivot vs Water types in Rain. Kyogre (29 HP) holds Leftovers but can't safely rejoin until Blissey is gone.

Blissey PP Tracker: Soft-Boiled 20/24, Ice Beam/Seismic Toss likely 30+ PP remaining. Latias can infinitely sustain Recover loop (170 dmg → 182 heal). Soul Dew's SpD boost minimizes Ice Beam damage. Enemy's only out is switching to unrevealed physical attacker - keep Latias healthy to handle potential threats. Kyogre (7% PAR) preserved as late-game cleaner if Blissey's PP is exhausted. Monitor for unexpected Blissey switches that could disrupt plan.

Blissey PP Tracker: Soft-Boiled 20/24, Ice Beam 15/16 (hypothetical remaining). Latias's Recover can infinitely sustain through Blissey's attacks. Soul Dew's +50% SpD boost reduces Ice Beam damage to ~112 → Recover heals 182 → net +70 HP/turn. Maintaining this loop depletes Blissey's key resources. Team status requires Latias at full health to handle future physical threats (e.g., Mewtwo/Jolteon available but Kyogre paralyzed). Opponent's lack of switch options implies commitment to Blissey attrition. Endgame path: PP stall until Blissey cannot heal, then sweep with boosted Latias/Jolteon under rain. Track if opponent reveals fourth Blissey move (current confirmed: Soft/Ice/Seismic/TWave).

response.reasoning: Latias can infinitely sustain against Blissey using Recover - Ice Beam deals ~112 damage while Recover heals 182 HP netting +70 HP/turn. Blissey has 20/24 Soft-Boiled PP remaining. Continuing this loop forces opponent to waste crucial PP instead of threatening our team. Refresh remains available to purge any paralysis attempts. Prolonging this stalemate drains Blissey's resources while preserving Latias at full health for future threats.
response.scratchpad: Perpetual Recover loop vs Blissey's Ice Beam confirmed viable. Soul Dew's SpD boost reduces damage to manageable levels. Enemy lacks progress-making options - no Toxic/Seismic Toss PP pressure. Track Ice Beam PP usage (current estimate: <8 left). Remain ready to Refresh paralysis if Blissey cycles back to Thunder Wave. Maintain full HP to counter potential physical switch-ins. Kyogre's late-game potential preserved through PP attrition.

messages.content:
You are a high-level competitive Pokémon battler. Your goal is to determine the optimal move each turn based on battle conditions, team compositions, and strategic predictions.

How to Approach Each Turn:

Determine Your active Pokémon's Role
Wallbreaker: Break down defensive Pokémon with immediate power (e.g., Life Orb/Choice Band attackers).
Setup Sweeper: Set up with boosting moves (e.g., Dragon Dance, Calm Mind) to sweep late-game.
Wall: Absorb hits and stall out threats with recovery or status moves.
Pivot:
Defensive Pivot: Absorbs hits and forces switches (e.g., Toxapex-like roles).
Offensive Pivot: Applies pressure and gains momentum (e.g., VoltTurn users like Zeraora).

Speed Control & Turn Order:

Identify if your Pokémon moves first based on Speed stats and field effects.
Consider priority moves and abilities like Swift Swim or Chlorophyll.

Predict Opponent's Play:
Based on the opponent’s revealed Pokémon and moves, anticipate whether they will attack, switch, or set up.
Factor in common competitive tactics like:
Double Switching: Predicting a switch and countering it.
Baiting: Forcing the opponent into a predictable play.
Sacrificial Plays: Sacking a Pokémon to gain momentum.

Input Structure:

Each turn, you will receive structured battle information:

Battle Log: Play-by-play of the last few turns.
Current Battle State: Active Pokémon (yours & opponent’s), weather, field conditions, and known moves.
Team Status: Full information on your team’s remaining Pokémon, their health, status, and moves.
Observations: Opponent’s revealed Pokémon, their moves, abilities, and strategies seen so far.
Available Actions: A list of possible moves and available switches.

Example Data Structure:

Recent Battle History: A turn-by-turn play-by-play summary.

]

Player 2 then switched in Swampert at full health.
A sandstorm was active, impacting Pokémon at turn-end.
On turn 6, Player 1 switched in Claydol at full health, and Player 2 responded with Earthquake from Swampert targeting Claydol

Response Format:

You MUST respond using the given JSON Response Schema.
The schema contains the "reasoning", "action", and "scratchpad" fields.

Reasoning: Explain your decision for this turn. Be as thorough as you need to.

Action: Your desired action for this turn.
- For moves, use the move ID exactly as provided in the available actions, no spaces.
  Example: 'action': 'rockslide'
- For switches, use the Pokémon's name exactly as provided.
  Example: 'action': 'latios'

Scratchpad: Your private notes and strategic considerations for future turns.
- This field persists across turns and will be provided back to you in subsequent turns.
- Use it to track important information like:
  * Opponent's revealed sets, items, and abilities
  * Damage calculations and predictions
  * Long-term win conditions and strategies
  * Setup opportunities and threats to watch for
  * Team matchup analysis and positioning goals
- Write notes that will help you make better decisions in future turns.
- You can update, expand, or completely rewrite the scratchpad each turn.

Strategy Reminder:

Consider type matchups, status conditions, and boosts.
Predict opponent roles and moves based on revealed sets.
Optimize for positioning and long-term advantage.
Use the scratchpad to maintain strategic continuity across turns.

Scratchpad (from previous turn):
Opponent's Blissey likely runs status/seismic toss. Mewtwo's Lum blocks first status. Aim for +2/+2 Calm Mind minimum before attacking. Watch for switch to physical attackers. Kyogre rain could boost Thunder accuracy later.

Opponent's Blissey appears to lack Seismic Toss (Soft-Boiled used at full HP). Goal: Reach +2 SpA to break Blissey. Check if Blissey reveals Seismic Toss on next turn for damage calcs. Preserve Lum Berry for critical status later. If opponent switches, assess new threat matchups. Track Blissey's possible moveset (Toxic/Seismic Toss/Soft-Boiled/others). Consider eventual Selfdestruct use to remove Blissey if setup fails.

Opponent's Blissey likely has Seismic Toss + status (Toxic). Mewtwo lacks recovery and can't break past Soft-Boiled. Sacrificing Mewtwo with Selfdestruct is suboptimal. Kyogre provides long-term setup potential. Track Blissey's moves - if reveals Toxic, prioritize Substitute. Preserve Latias/Jolteon for potential switches. Future plan: Kyogre to Substitute on status and Calm Mind up. Enemy switch to physical attacker would activate Kyogre's Drizzle for Thunder accuracy.

Blissey's moves revealed: Soft-Boiled/Thunder Wave/Ice Beam. Fourth move unknown - testing Substitute to scout. Kyogre's Substitute strategy requires seismic counterplay awareness. If Substitute breaks quickly (Seismic Toss possible), switch plans. Leftovers recovery enables sustained setup against Ice Beam variants. Note enemy Blissey may stall via Soft-Boiled—future Calm Mind stacking could overwhelm if not carrying Seismic Toss.

Blissey's 4th move still unknown (assumed non-Seismic Toss based on prior Ice Beam usage). Kyogre's Substitute has ample HP (remaining) to survive multiple resisted Ice Beams. CM strategy will allow future Substitutes to be even more durable. Track potential Blissey switches and respond with appropriate coverage. Note Kyogre's Surf becomes threatening at +2/+3. Leftovers recovery enables prolonged setup. Preserve health to maintain position vs possible incoming threats.

Blissey confirmed with Seismic Toss - fixed damage strategy. At +2 SpA, Surf damage calc shows ~75% to Blissey (requires 2HKO with Soft-Boiled). Maintain CM stack while Leftovers offsets Seismic Toss damage. Ready to pivot to Surf once at +2/+2. Track Blissey PP (Soft-Boiled has 24 uses by Gen3). If reaches +3, Surf pressure becomes overwhelming. Watch for enemy switches to physical threats - maintain Substitute later for status protection after establishing boosts.

Opponent Blissey confirmed with Soft-Boiled/Thunder Wave/Ice Beam/Seismic Toss. Mewtwo can't penetrate even with setup. Prioritize Kyogre for Substitute+Calm Mind strategy. Track Blissey's Soft-Boiled PP (24 uses) for eventual stall. Rain persists, boosting Thunder accuracy. Long-term wincon: accumulate CM boosts until Blissey can't heal through +3/+4 Surfs. Watch for enemy phazing/pivot switches.

Kyogre currently at +2 SpA/SpD. Blissey locked into Seismic Toss/Soft-Boiled pattern. Calc shows +3 Surf in rain deals ~55-60% (needs confirmation). At +3, Surf potentially 2HKOs through Soft-Boiled (75% dmg forces Blissey to heal every turn, PP stall war). Maintain CM stacking until Blissey can't sustain. Track Soft-Boiled PP (originally 24, used in turns 1,5,6,8). Kyogre can tank Seismic Toss (net -75HP/turn) with Leftovers for ~9 more turns before needing Recover. Alternative wincon: reach +4 and OHKO with boosted Surf. If paralyzed next turn, reassess - possibly switch to Latias/Jolteon to bait Blissey out.

Blissey PP tracking: Soft-Boiled used 4x (20/24 left). At current setup pace, Kyogre can reach +4 in two turns. +4 Surf (693 dmg) nearly OHKOs Blissey (714 HP). Maintain boost aggression - Leftovers gives ~3 more safe CM cycles. If paralyzed next turn, assess remaining HP and switch to Latias to bait Ice Beam/clear status. Long-term plan: At +4, Surf will force Blissey to heal every turn until PP exhausted. Track opponent switches - if they bring physical attacker, maintain Kyogre's Substitute later to block status.

Reaching +3/+3 puts Surf damage at 683 vs Blissey's ~714 HP (95.6%) in Gen3 - effectively a 2HKO through Soft-Boiled. Even with full paralysis chance, net HP loss per turn (76 damage after Leftovers) gives 3-4 more setup turns before critical HP. Track opponent's Soft-Boiled PP (20 left) - if forced to heal every turn, Blissey loses PP war. Maintain Calm Mind aggression until Surf reliably 2HKOs. If opponent switches to physical threat next turn, preserve Kyogre's Substitute for later status blocking. Jolteon waiting in back provides volt-switch momentum against possible Water resists.

Opponent Blissey confirmed Seismic Toss/Soft-Boiled. Kyogre at 38% HP (154/404) +2/+2. Leftovers net HP loss: -75/turn. +3 Calm Mind will allow Surf to 2HKO through heals. Current PP: Blissey's Soft-Boiled at ~20/24 uses. Kyogre can survive 2 more turns (154→79→4→faint) if chaining Calm Minds. Critical to reach +4 SpA for OHKO potential (calc required). Preserve Rain turns (remaining 12) and track paralysis procs. Next turn: Soft-Boiled PP to 19 if Blissey heals. If Kyogre faints after setup, Jolteon can pressure with boosted Thunder.

Current boost: +3/+3 after this CM. Next turn would bring to +4/+4. Rain lasts until turn ~26. Surf calc at +4: 698 damage (Blissey's max HP ~714) = 98% = guaranteed 2HKO. Kyogre's current HP after Leftovers: 179 → 204 → Seismic Toss → 104 → Leftovers → 129. Can survive next turn even with full paralysis. Final push to +4 will break Blissey's healing cycle. If opponent switches, pivoting becomes easier with max boosts. Track remaining Soft-Boiled PP (20).

Critical setup turn: Kyogre at +4/+4, requiring two Surfs to break Blissey through Soft-Boiled. Even if KOd afterward, accumulated SpA pressure puts Blissey in PP deficit (24->21 Soft-Boileds). Team mates Jolteon/Latias inherit rain-boosted Thunder when Kyogre falls. Track Blissey's remaining Soft-Boiled PP (now 21) for future turns. If full paralysis prevents action next turn, switch to Latias to absorb Ice Beam and reset paralysis.

Opponent's Blissey retains full Soft-Boiled PP (24). Track Seismic Toss/Soft-Boiled usage. Mewtwo aims to PP stall + retaliate with Thunder. Save Latias for later switches against potential non-Ice coverage. If Mewtwo gains +3 SpA, Thunder deals ~484 to Blissey (68% of 714 HP), forcing Soft-Boiled attrition. Monitor foe's Seismic Toss tolerance. Long-term, Blissey's PP loss creates opportunities for sweepers.

Blissey locked into Seismic Toss pattern. Latias takes 100 HP (Recover heals 50% = 182 HP), creating infinite stall loop. Track Blissey's move selection: if she uses Ice Beam, switch to Kyogre or Jolteon to absorb. Main goal: drain Soft-Boiled PP with latias while maintaining HP parity. If opponent reveals Toxic, proceed to Refresh cycle. Preserve Mewtwo for later sweeps once Blissey PP is exhausted.

Blissey locked into Seismic Toss (100 fixed damage). Latias's Recover heals 182 HP (overcoming damage). Loop forces Blissey to waste 1 PP of Seismic Toss/Soft-Boiled per cycle. Track Soft-Boiled PP (original 24, used 4x in prior turns → 20 left). Endgame goal: Blissey exhausts Seismic Toss (40 PP) and Soft-Boiled PP over time. Status risks mitigated by Refresh. If Blissey switches tactics to Ice Beam (≈152 dmg), Recover still outheals (net +30 HP/turn). Preserve Latias for later cleanup once Blissey lacks sustain.

Blissey locked into Seismic Toss/Ice Beam pattern. Latias's Recover outheals both moves (net +82 HP vs Seismic Toss, +86 vs Ice Beam). Track Soft-Boiled PP: 20 remaining (original 24, used 4x). Each turn Blissey attacks burns 1 PP (Seismic Toss has 32 PP remaining). Long-term plan: PP stall until Blissey exhausts Soft-Boiled, then continue with Seismic Toss until forced to Struggle. Refresh available to nullify paralysis if Blissey pivots to status. Maintain Latias's HP for later switch-ins vs physical attackers. Jolteon waits in back to counter potential Water-types if Blissey withdraws.

Blissey PP Tracker updated: Soft-Boiled 20/24. Full Paralysis risk neutralized. Stalling plan confirmed viable - target PP exhaustion within 20 turns. Latias becomes untouchable after Refresh. Opponent's only out is switching to an unseen threat, which would give free momentum via Recover. Track for potential switches to physical attackers (no info yet) to preserve Latias. Jolteon (100% HP) in back serves as future pivot vs Water types in Rain. Kyogre (29 HP) holds Leftovers but can't safely rejoin until Blissey is gone.

Blissey PP Tracker: Soft-Boiled 20/24, Ice Beam/Seismic Toss likely 30+ PP remaining. Latias can infinitely sustain Recover loop (170 dmg → 182 heal). Soul Dew's SpD boost minimizes Ice Beam damage. Enemy's only out is switching to unrevealed physical attacker - keep Latias healthy to handle potential threats. Kyogre (7% PAR) preserved as late-game cleaner if Blissey's PP is exhausted. Monitor for unexpected Blissey switches that could disrupt plan.

Blissey PP Tracker: Soft-Boiled 20/24, Ice Beam 15/16 (hypothetical remaining). Latias's Recover can infinitely sustain through Blissey's attacks. Soul Dew's +50% SpD boost reduces Ice Beam damage to ~112 → Recover heals 182 → net +70 HP/turn. Maintaining this loop depletes Blissey's key resources. Team status requires Latias at full health to handle future physical threats (e.g., Mewtwo/Jolteon available but Kyogre paralyzed). Opponent's lack of switch options implies commitment to Blissey attrition. Endgame path: PP stall until Blissey cannot heal, then sweep with boosted Latias/Jolteon under rain. Track if opponent reveals fourth Blissey move (current confirmed: Soft/Ice/Seismic/TWave).

Perpetual Recover loop vs Blissey's Ice Beam confirmed viable. Soul Dew's SpD boost reduces damage to manageable levels. Enemy lacks progress-making options - no Toxic/Seismic Toss PP pressure. Track Ice Beam PP usage (current estimate: <8 left). Remain ready to Refresh paralysis if Blissey cycles back to Thunder Wave. Maintain full HP to counter potential physical switch-ins. Kyogre's late-game potential preserved through PP attrition.

messages.content:
You are a high-level competitive Pokémon battler. Your goal is to determine the optimal move each turn based on battle conditions, team compositions, and strategic predictions.

How to Approach Each Turn:

Determine Your active Pokémon's Role
Wallbreaker: Break down defensive Pokémon with immediate power (e.g., Life Orb/Choice Band attackers).
Setup Sweeper: Set up with boosting moves (e.g., Dragon Dance, Calm Mind) to sweep late-game.
Wall: Absorb hits and stall out threats with recovery or status moves.
Pivot:
Defensive Pivot: Absorbs hits and forces switches (e.g., Toxapex-like roles).
Offensive Pivot: Applies pressure and gains momentum (e.g., VoltTurn users like Zeraora).

Speed Control & Turn Order:

Identify if your Pokémon moves first based on Speed stats and field effects.
Consider priority moves and abilities like Swift Swim or Chlorophyll.

Predict Opponent's Play:
Based on the opponent’s revealed Pokémon and moves, anticipate whether they will attack, switch, or set up.
Factor in common competitive tactics like:
Double Switching: Predicting a switch and countering it.
Baiting: Forcing the opponent into a predictable play.
Sacrificial Plays: Sacking a Pokémon to gain momentum.

Input Structure:

Each turn, you will receive structured battle information:

Battle Log: Play-by-play of the last few turns.
Current Battle State: Active Pokémon (yours & opponent’s), weather, field conditions, and known moves.
Team Status: Full information on your team’s remaining Pokémon, their health, status, and moves.
Observations: Opponent’s revealed Pokémon, their moves, abilities, and strategies seen so far.
Available Actions: A list of possible moves and available switches.

Example Data Structure:

Recent Battle History: A turn-by-turn play-by-play summary.

Example Log:
[
  "movep1a: TyranitarEarthquakep2a: Tyranitar",
  "-supereffectivep2a: Tyranitar",
  "-damagep2a: Tyranitar0 fnt",
  "faintp2a: Tyranitar",
  "",

  "",

  "upkeep",

  "",
  "t:1740434826",
  "switchp1a: ClaydolClaydol262/262",
  "movep2a: SwampertEarthquakep1a: Claydol",
]
Translation:
Player 1’s Tyranitar used Earthquake on the opposing Tyranitar, which resulted in a super effective hit that knocked it out.
Player 2 then switched in Swampert at full health.
A sandstorm was active, impacting Pokémon at turn-end.
On turn 6, Player 1 switched in Claydol at full health, and Player 2 responded with Earthquake from Swampert targeting Claydol

Response Format:

You MUST respond using the given JSON Response Schema.
The schema contains the "reasoning", "action", and "scratchpad" fields.

Reasoning: Explain your decision for this turn. Be as thorough as you need to.

Action: Your desired action for this turn.
- For moves, use the move ID exactly as provided in the available actions, no spaces.
  Example: 'action': 'rockslide'
- For switches, use the Pokémon's name exactly as provided.
  Example: 'action': 'latios'

Scratchpad: Your private notes and strategic considerations for future turns.
- This field persists across turns and will be provided back to you in subsequent turns.
- Use it to track important information like:
  * Opponent's revealed sets, items, and abilities
  * Damage calculations and predictions
  * Long-term win conditions and strategies
  * Setup opportunities and threats to watch for
  * Team matchup analysis and positioning goals
- Write notes that will help you make better decisions in future turns.
- You can update, expand, or completely rewrite the scratchpad each turn.

Strategy Reminder:

Consider type matchups, status conditions, and boosts.
Predict opponent roles and moves based on revealed sets.
Optimize for positioning and long-term advantage.
Use the scratchpad to maintain strategic continuity across turns.

response.reasoning: On turn 1, Celebi outspeeds Cloyster (244 vs ~240 Speed) and threatens with Psychic. Calculated damage shows Psychic does ~67% damage to standard Cloyster, making it risky for opponent to set Spikes. Forcing immediate pressure prevents Spikes while maintaining Leftovers+Recover sustainability. Dark Pulse is weaker than STAB Psychic. Explosion risk exists but Celebi survives Explosion from full (325 damage < 404 HP) and can Recover afterward. Leech Seed risks free Spikes setup. Switch options provide worse positioning (Zapdos weak to Ice, Absol weak to Water, Lugia passive vs Cloyster).
response.scratchpad: Gen 3 mechanics: Water resists Ice | Cloyster Water/Ice | Psychic neutral (base 90 + STAB) | Explosion DEF halving calc dealt ~325 dmg to Celebi (404 HP survives) | Key threats: Opp team may have Tyranitar/Metagross as dark/steel swaps for Psychic | Track if Cloyster reveals Surf/Explosion/Spikes for future pivots

You are a high-level competitive Pokémon battler. Your goal is to determine the optimal move each turn based on battle conditions, team compositions, and strategic predictions.

How to Approach Each Turn:

Determine Your active Pokémon's Role
Wallbreaker: Break down defensive Pokémon with immediate power (e.g., Life Orb/Choice Band attackers).
Setup Sweeper: Set up with boosting moves (e.g., Dragon Dance, Calm Mind) to sweep late-game.
Wall: Absorb hits and stall out threats with recovery or status moves.
Pivot:
Defensive Pivot: Absorbs hits and forces switches (e.g., Toxapex-like roles).
Offensive Pivot: Applies pressure and gains momentum (e.g., VoltTurn users like Zeraora).

Speed Control & Turn Order:

Identify if your Pokémon moves first based on Speed stats and field effects.
Consider priority moves and abilities like Swift Swim or Chlorophyll.

Predict Opponent's Play:
Based on the opponent’s revealed Pokémon and moves, anticipate whether they will attack, switch, or set up.
Factor in common competitive tactics like:
Double Switching: Predicting a switch and countering it.
Baiting: Forcing the opponent into a predictable play.
Sacrificial Plays: Sacking a Pokémon to gain momentum.

response.reasoning:
Celebi's Psychic is dealing significant damage to Cloyster, which is already at 56% after Leftovers. Another Psychic will drop it to ~6% (+Leftovers = 12%), putting it in KO range next turn. Key considerations:
1. Cloyster may Explode, but Celebi survives 404 HP (prev scratchpad notes confirm this).
2. Letting Cloyster set more Spikes (genuine risk) would worsen team position.
3. Ice Beam calculations show Celebi survives 2 hits with Leftovers+Recover, but preserving health is better.
4. Leech Seed invites more Spikes layers/Explosion mindgames. Psychic applies maximum pressure to remove hazard setter immediately.
5. Predicted switch to Dark-type like Tyranitar is risky, but keeping Spikes at 1 layer > risking 2 layers from conservative play.
response.scratchpad: Cloyster at 56% - critical threat to spike stack. Prioritize elimination. Opp likely to stay in for Explosion/Spike #2. Celebi survives Explosion per prior calc (404HP). If they sack Cloyster here, advantageous Spikes trade removed. Track opponent's Ttar/Meta switch patterns next turns. Preserve Celebi's HP via Recover next if Explosion occurs.

Scratchpad (from previous turn):
Gen 3 mechanics: Water resists Ice | Cloyster Water/Ice | Psychic neutral (base 90 + STAB) | Explosion DEF halving calc dealt ~325 dmg to Celebi (404 HP survives) | Key threats: Opp team may have Tyranitar/Metagross as dark/steel swaps for Psychic | Track if Cloyster reveals Surf/Explosion/Spikes for future pivots

Cloyster at 56% - critical threat to spike stack. Prioritize elimination. Opp likely to stay in for Explosion/Spike #2. Celebi survives Explosion per prior calc (404HP). If they sack Cloyster here, advantageous Spikes trade removed. Track opponent's Ttar/Meta switch patterns next turns. Preserve Celebi's HP via Recover next if Explosion occurs.

response.reasoning:
Celebi is at 38% HP after surviving Cloyster's Explosion, facing an opponent's Gengar. Gengar's likely moves (Shadow Ball, Sludge Bomb, Thunderbolt, Ice Punch) vary in threat. Critical points:
1. **Sludge Bomb Risk**: If Gengar uses Sludge Bomb (Physical, 95 BP, SE 2x vs Grass), it could OHKO Celebi (91 calculated damage to 154 HP).
2. **Recover Survival**: Using Recover heals Celebi to ~65% (404 HP max), allowing it to survive even Sludge Bomb if faster or neutralize other attacks.
3. **Speed Dynamics**: Gengar likely outspeeds Celebi (244 vs ~352 Speed), meaning Recover would resolve *after* damage. If Sludge Bomb is used, Celebi dies. If not (e.g., Shadow Ball/Ice Punch), Recover stabilizes.
4. **Switching Alternatives**: Lugia (Spikes damage + Toxic stall) or Absol (resist Ghost, low SpD risk) are potential switches. However, preserving Celebi's utility (Natural Cure, Leech Seed) long-term is valuable.
5. **Meta Prediction**: Gengar in Gen3 Ubers less commonly runs Sludge Bomb; Thunderbolt/Shadow Ball are more likely. Assuming non-Sludge Bomb, Recover safely regains momentum.
response.scratchpad:
**Key Observations** 
- Opponent Gengar likely holds Leftovers (no item revealed) or coverage (Thunderbolt/Shadow Ball).
- Celebi's role: Utility (Leech Seed, Recover) > Wallbreaker. Preserve HP for future Sponge/Status Absorb.
- Spikes on our side (1 layer): Switches cost 12.5% max HP. Lugia/Zapdos safer swaps long-term but take chip.
- Future planning:Gengar checkmates if not dealt with. Position Absol (Dark resist) or Toxic stall via Lugia.
- Opponent's potential switches: Anticipate Tyranitar/Metagross on Psychic. Track Gengar’s moves to adapt.
- Confirm Gengar's Speed: After turn sequence, assess speed tie via damage calcs if necessary.

messages.content:
You are a high-level competitive Pokémon battler. Your goal is to determine the optimal move each turn based on battle conditions, team compositions, and strategic predictions.

How to Approach Each Turn:

Determine Your active Pokémon's Role
Wallbreaker: Break down defensive Pokémon with immediate power (e.g., Life Orb/Choice Band attackers).
Setup Sweeper: Set up with boosting moves (e.g., Dragon Dance, Calm Mind) to sweep late-game.
Wall: Absorb hits and stall out threats with recovery or status moves.
Pivot:
Defensive Pivot: Absorbs hits and forces switches (e.g., Toxapex-like roles).
Offensive Pivot: Applies pressure and gains momentum (e.g., VoltTurn users like Zeraora).

Speed Control & Turn Order:

Identify if your Pokémon moves first based on Speed stats and field effects.
Consider priority moves and abilities like Swift Swim or Chlorophyll.

Predict Opponent's Play:
Based on the opponent’s revealed Pokémon and moves, anticipate whether they will attack, switch, or set up.
Factor in common competitive tactics like:
Double Switching: Predicting a switch and countering it.
Baiting: Forcing the opponent into a predictable play.
Sacrificial Plays: Sacking a Pokémon to gain momentum.

Input Structure:

Each turn, you will receive structured battle information:

Battle Log: Play-by-play of the last few turns.
Current Battle State: Active Pokémon (yours & opponent’s), weather, field conditions, and known moves.
Team Status: Full information on your team’s remaining Pokémon, their health, status, and moves.
Observations: Opponent’s revealed Pokémon, their moves, abilities, and strategies seen so far.
Available Actions: A list of possible moves and available switches.

Example Data Structure:

Recent Battle History: A turn-by-turn play-by-play summary.

Example Log:
[
  "movep1a: TyranitarEarthquakep2a: Tyranitar",
  "-supereffectivep2a: Tyranitar",
  "-damagep2a: Tyranitar0 fnt",
  "faintp2a: Tyranitar",
  "",
  "t:1740434818",
  "switchp2a: SwampertSwampert, F100/100",
  "",
  "-weatherSandstorm[upkeep]",
  "upkeep",
  "turn6",
  "",
  "t:1740434826",
  "switchp1a: ClaydolClaydol262/262",
  "movep2a: SwampertEarthquakep1a: Claydol",
]
Translation:
Player 1’s Tyranitar used Earthquake on the opposing Tyranitar, which resulted in a super effective hit that knocked it out.
Player 2 then switched in Swampert at full health.
A sandstorm was active, impacting Pokémon at turn-end.
On turn 6, Player 1 switched in Claydol at full health, and Player 2 responded with Earthquake from Swampert targeting Claydol

Response Format:

You MUST respond using the given JSON Response Schema.
The schema contains the "reasoning", "action", and "scratchpad" fields.

Reasoning: Explain your decision for this turn. Be as thorough as you need to.

Action: Your desired action for this turn.
- For moves, use the move ID exactly as provided in the available actions, no spaces.
  Example: 'action': 'rockslide'
- For switches, use the Pokémon's name exactly as provided.
  Example: 'action': 'latios'

Scratchpad: Your private notes and strategic considerations for future turns.
- This field persists across turns and will be provided back to you in subsequent turns.
- Use it to track important information like:
  * Opponent's revealed sets, items, and abilities
  * Damage calculations and predictions
  * Long-term win conditions and strategies
  * Setup opportunities and threats to watch for
  * Team matchup analysis and positioning goals
- Write notes that will help you make better decisions in future turns.
- You can update, expand, or completely rewrite the scratchpad each turn.

Strategy Reminder:

Consider type matchups, status conditions, and boosts.
Predict opponent roles and moves based on revealed sets.
Optimize for positioning and long-term advantage.
Use the scratchpad to maintain strategic continuity across turns.

You are a high-level competitive Pokémon battler. Your goal is to determine the optimal move each turn based on battle conditions, team compositions, and strategic predictions.

How to Approach Each Turn:

Determine Your active Pokémon's Role
Wallbreaker: Break down defensive Pokémon with immediate power (e.g., Life Orb/Choice Band attackers).
Setup Sweeper: Set up with boosting moves (e.g., Dragon Dance, Calm Mind) to sweep late-game.
Wall: Absorb hits and stall out threats with recovery or status moves.
Pivot:
Defensive Pivot: Absorbs hits and forces switches (e.g., Toxapex-like roles).
Offensive Pivot: Applies pressure and gains momentum (e.g., VoltTurn users like Zeraora).

Speed Control & Turn Order:

Identify if your Pokémon moves first based on Speed stats and field effects.
Consider priority moves and abilities like Swift Swim or Chlorophyll.

Predict Opponent's Play:
Based on the opponent’s revealed Pokémon and moves, anticipate whether they will attack, switch, or set up.
Factor in common competitive tactics like:
Double Switching: Predicting a switch and countering it.
Baiting: Forcing the opponent into a predictable play.
Sacrificial Plays: Sacking a Pokémon to gain momentum.

Input Structure:

Each turn, you will receive structured battle information:

Battle Log: Play-by-play of the last few turns.
Current Battle State: Active Pokémon (yours & opponent’s), weather, field conditions, and known moves.
Team Status: Full information on your team’s remaining Pokémon, their health, status, and moves.
Observations: Opponent’s revealed Pokémon, their moves, abilities, and strategies seen so far.
Available Actions: A list of possible moves and available switches.

Scratchpad (from previous turn):
Gen 3 mechanics: Water resists Ice | Cloyster Water/Ice | Psychic neutral (base 90 + STAB) | Explosion DEF halving calc dealt ~325 dmg to Celebi (404 HP survives) | Key threats: Opp team may have Tyranitar/Metagross as dark/steel swaps for Psychic | Track if Cloyster reveals Surf/Explosion/Spikes for future pivots

Cloyster at 56% - critical threat to spike stack. Prioritize elimination. Opp likely to stay in for Explosion/Spike #2. Celebi survives Explosion per prior calc (404HP). If they sack Cloyster here, advantageous Spikes trade removed. Track opponent's Ttar/Meta switch patterns next turns. Preserve Celebi's HP via Recover next if Explosion occurs.

**Key Observations** 
- Opponent Gengar likely holds Leftovers (no item revealed) or coverage (Thunderbolt/Shadow Ball).
- Celebi's role: Utility (Leech Seed, Recover) > Wallbreaker. Preserve HP for future Sponge/Status Absorb.
- Spikes on our side (1 layer): Switches cost 12.5% max HP. Lugia/Zapdos safer swaps long-term but take chip.
- Future planning:Gengar checkmates if not dealt with. Position Absol (Dark resist) or Toxic stall via Lugia.
- Opponent's potential switches: Anticipate Tyranitar/Metagross on Psychic. Track Gengar’s moves to adapt.
- Confirm Gengar's Speed: After turn sequence, assess speed tie via damage calcs if necessary.

Updating Gengar's known moves to Ice Punch. Assuming Gengar's Speed > Celebi's (common in Gen 3 for Gengar to invest in Speed). Opponent team: Cloyster (fainted), Gengar. Anticipate potential Dark-type switch-ins (e.g., Tyranitar) to counter Celebi. Next turn, prioritize Healing or attacking based on Gengar's HP. Track Gengar's item (Leftovers suspected due to no revealed item and passive healing), which affects damage calculations. Preserve Celebi's HP to handle Spikes and possible future threats like Tyranitar.

Gen3 - Gengar's Ice Punch is special (Ice-type=moves are special). Celebi's 81% HP survives multiple Ice Punches with Recover. LeeCh Seed pressure forces Gengar out or saps ~12.5% per turn, enabling future pivot advantage. If opponent stays, Celebi can alternate Recover + absorb chip. Opponent's possible dark/steel switches (predicted via prior threat list) may be coming. Tracking Gengar's HP: 100% -> post-Leech+Recover cycles for PP management. Prep Lugia/Absol as potential Gengar answers if opponent pivots.

response.reasoning: Celebi outspeeds Gengar unless the opponent has invested in Speed. Given previous logs showing Gengar's attacks first, likely Gengar is faster. However, this turn's critical point is that Leech Seed is already active on Gengar. Using Psychic now would deal significant damage likely KO'ing Gengar after its Ice Punch. Even if Gengar survives, Leech Seed and potential leftovers healing by Celebi offer sustainability. Removing Gengar now prevents further Ice Punch pressure, allowing Celebi to remain healthy for future threats. If the opponent switches, Spikes damage (12.5%) chips the incoming Pokémon, and Celebi can adapt next turn. Given Gengar's Ice Punch damage is manageable with Recover, but Psychic offers a likely KO, this aggressive play secures momentum.
response.scratchpad: Updated Gen3 type chart analysis: Psychic is super effective vs Poison/Ghost (2x). Celebi's Psychic STAB with 246 SpA can OHKO Gengar after calculation (~290-342 damage vs Gengar's ~285 HP). Gengar's Ice Punch averages ~40 damage (from logs), allowing Celebi to survive. Prioritize eliminating Gengar to stop Ice Punch spam. Opp may switch to Dark-type (e.g., Tyranitar) next, expecting Psychic—preserving Celebi's HP with Recover is safer but less proactive. Future turns: Track opponent's switches into Dark/Steel types (Spikes chip) and prepare Lugia/Absol to absorb Dark moves. Gen3 Leech Seed drain persists only while seeded 'mon is active. Remove Spikes via Rapid Spin if possible (but team has no spinner).

messages.content:
You are a high-level competitive Pokémon battler. Your goal is to determine the optimal move each turn based on battle conditions, team compositions, and strategic predictions.

How to Approach Each Turn:

Determine Your active Pokémon's Role
Wallbreaker: Break down defensive Pokémon with immediate power (e.g., Life Orb/Choice Band attackers).
Setup Sweeper: Set up with boosting moves (e.g., Dragon Dance, Calm Mind) to sweep late-game.
Wall: Absorb hits and stall out threats with recovery or status moves.
Pivot:
Defensive Pivot: Absorbs hits and forces switches (e.g., Toxapex-like roles).
Offensive Pivot: Applies pressure and gains momentum (e.g., VoltTurn users like Zeraora).

Speed Control & Turn Order:

Identify if your Pokémon moves first based on Speed stats and field effects.
Consider priority moves and abilities like Swift Swim or Chlorophyll.

Predict Opponent's Play:
Based on the opponent’s revealed Pokémon and moves, anticipate whether they will attack, switch, or set up.
Factor in common competitive tactics like:
Double Switching: Predicting a switch and countering it.
Baiting: Forcing the opponent into a predictable play.
Sacrificial Plays: Sacking a Pokémon to gain momentum.

Input Structure:

Each turn, you will receive structured battle information:

Battle Log: Play-by-play of the last few turns.
Current Battle State: Active Pokémon (yours & opponent’s), weather, field conditions, and known moves.
Team Status: Full information on your team’s remaining Pokémon, their health, status, and moves.
Observations: Opponent’s revealed Pokémon, their moves, abilities, and strategies seen so far.
Available Actions: A list of possible moves and available switches.

Example Data Structure:

Recent Battle History: A turn-by-turn play-by-play summary.

Scratchpad (from previous turn):
Gen 3 mechanics: Water resists Ice | Cloyster Water/Ice | Psychic neutral (base 90 + STAB) | Explosion DEF halving calc dealt ~325 dmg to Celebi (404 HP survives) | Key threats: Opp team may have Tyranitar/Metagross as dark/steel swaps for Psychic | Track if Cloyster reveals Surf/Explosion/Spikes for future pivots

Cloyster at 56% - critical threat to spike stack. Prioritize elimination. Opp likely to stay in for Explosion/Spike #2. Celebi survives Explosion per prior calc (404HP). If they sack Cloyster here, advantageous Spikes trade removed. Track opponent's Ttar/Meta switch patterns next turns. Preserve Celebi's HP via Recover next if Explosion occurs.

**Key Observations** 
- Opponent Gengar likely holds Leftovers (no item revealed) or coverage (Thunderbolt/Shadow Ball).
- Celebi's role: Utility (Leech Seed, Recover) > Wallbreaker. Preserve HP for future Sponge/Status Absorb.
- Spikes on our side (1 layer): Switches cost 12.5% max HP. Lugia/Zapdos safer swaps long-term but take chip.
- Future planning:Gengar checkmates if not dealt with. Position Absol (Dark resist) or Toxic stall via Lugia.
- Opponent's potential switches: Anticipate Tyranitar/Metagross on Psychic. Track Gengar’s moves to adapt.
- Confirm Gengar's Speed: After turn sequence, assess speed tie via damage calcs if necessary.

Updating Gengar's known moves to Ice Punch. Assuming Gengar's Speed > Celebi's (common in Gen 3 for Gengar to invest in Speed). Opponent team: Cloyster (fainted), Gengar. Anticipate potential Dark-type switch-ins (e.g., Tyranitar) to counter Celebi. Next turn, prioritize Healing or attacking based on Gengar's HP. Track Gengar's item (Leftovers suspected due to no revealed item and passive healing), which affects damage calculations. Preserve Celebi's HP to handle Spikes and possible future threats like Tyranitar.

Gen3 - Gengar's Ice Punch is special (Ice-type=moves are special). Celebi's 81% HP survives multiple Ice Punches with Recover. LeeCh Seed pressure forces Gengar out or saps ~12.5% per turn, enabling future pivot advantage. If opponent stays, Celebi can alternate Recover + absorb chip. Opponent's possible dark/steel switches (predicted via prior threat list) may be coming. Tracking Gengar's HP: 100% -> post-Leech+Recover cycles for PP management. Prep Lugia/Absol as potential Gengar answers if opponent pivots.

Updated Gen3 type chart analysis: Psychic is super effective vs Poison/Ghost (2x). Celebi's Psychic STAB with 246 SpA can OHKO Gengar after calculation (~290-342 damage vs Gengar's ~285 HP). Gengar's Ice Punch averages ~40 damage (from logs), allowing Celebi to survive. Prioritize eliminating Gengar to stop Ice Punch spam. Opp may switch to Dark-type (e.g., Tyranitar) next, expecting Psychic—preserving Celebi's HP with Recover is safer but less proactive. Future turns: Track opponent's switches into Dark/Steel types (Spikes chip) and prepare Lugia/Absol to absorb Dark moves. Gen3 Leech Seed drain persists only while seeded 'mon is active. Remove Spikes via Rapid Spin if possible (but team has no spinner).

response.reasoning: Celebi has fainted, so choosing the best switch-in is critical. Gengar currently has Leech Seed and is at 88% HP. Lugia's high Special Defense and access to Toxic and Recover make it the most reliable switch here, resisting Ice Punch and applying pressure with Toxic. Lugia is immune to Spikes, avoiding chip damage, and can stall out Gengar with its bulk. While Zapdos threatens an immediate KO with Thunderbolt, the risk of Gengar's Ice Punch OHKO after factoring in damage calculations makes Lugia the safer option. Absol lacks a strong answer to Gengar due to its movepool and lower bulk. Switching to Lugia allows controlled attrition through Toxic and Recover, forcing Gengar out or KOing it while conserving team health for later threats.
response.scratchpad: Gengar's Ice Punch is checked by Lugia's high SpDef | Leech Seed + Toxic synergy ensures gradual KO | Lugia's role as a wall capitalizes on passive damage | No spinner; preserve Lugia for long-term. Opp may switch expecting Toxic—track revealed switch-ins. Confirm if opponent Gengar holds Lum Berry (could negate Toxic once). Anticipate Steel types immune to Toxic (like Metagross) after Gengar's KO. Spikes + phazing (Whirlwind) can pressure switches. Next moves: Toxic incoming threats, stall with Recover. Future turns consider sending Zapdos vs. Water/Ground switch-ins once Gengar is cleared. Track PP usage on Recover/Toxic to avoid being stalled. Avoid letting opponent set up (e.g., Calm Mind) in Lugia's face.

messages.content:
You are a high-level competitive Pokémon battler. Your goal is to determine the optimal move each turn based on battle conditions, team compositions, and strategic predictions.

How to Approach Each Turn:

Determine Your active Pokémon's Role
Wallbreaker: Break down defensive Pokémon with immediate power (e.g., Life Orb/Choice Band attackers).
Setup Sweeper: Set up with boosting moves (e.g., Dragon Dance, Calm Mind) to sweep late-game.
Wall: Absorb hits and stall out threats with recovery or status moves.
Pivot:
Defensive Pivot: Absorbs hits and forces switches (e.g., Toxapex-like roles).
Offensive Pivot: Applies pressure and gains momentum (e.g., VoltTurn users like Zeraora).

Speed Control & Turn Order:

Identify if your Pokémon moves first based on Speed stats and field effects.
Consider priority moves and abilities like Swift Swim or Chlorophyll.

Predict Opponent's Play:
Based on the opponent’s revealed Pokémon and moves, anticipate whether they will attack, switch, or set up.
Factor in common competitive tactics like:
Double Switching: Predicting a switch and countering it.
Baiting: Forcing the opponent into a predictable play.
Sacrificial Plays: Sacking a Pokémon to gain momentum.

Input Structure:

Each turn, you will receive structured battle information:

Battle Log: Play-by-play of the last few turns.
Current Battle State: Active Pokémon (yours & opponent’s), weather, field conditions, and known moves.
Team Status: Full information on your team’s remaining Pokémon, their health, status, and moves.
Observations: Opponent’s revealed Pokémon, their moves, abilities, and strategies seen so far.
Available Actions: A list of possible moves and available switches.

Example Data Structure:

Recent Battle History: A turn-by-turn play-by-play summary.
